title: 111_s859
content: The Act titled "Marine Mammal Rescue Assistance Amendments of 2009" amends the Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 to include entanglement response. This involves updating information on stranded or entangled marine mammals and establishing entanglement response agreements. The Marine Mammal Rescue Assistance Amendments of 2009 amends the Marine Mammal Protection Act to include entanglement response agreements. The Marine Mammal Rescue Assistance Amendments of 2009 amends the Marine Mammal Protection Act to include entanglement response agreements. It defines entanglement as gear, rope, line, net, or other material wrapped around a marine mammal in the wild. The Marine Mammal Rescue Assistance Amendments of 2009 amend the Marine Mammal Protection Act to include entanglement response agreements and funding for unusual mortality events. Amendments include changes to compensation for special costs and preparation, analysis, and transportation of events. The amendments to the Marine Mammal Protection Act include changes to compensation for special costs and transportation of events, with authorization of appropriations for the John H. Prescott Marine Mammal Rescue and Response Funding Program. The John H. Prescott Marine Mammal Rescue and Rapid Response Fund is authorized to receive $7,000,000 annually from 2010 to 2014, with $6,000,000 allocated to the Secretary of Commerce and $1,000,000 to the Secretary of the Interior. An additional $500,000 is authorized for the Rapid Response Fund each year. Up to $500,000 per fiscal year can be deposited into the Fund from appropriations to the Secretary for implementing the Act. The John H. Prescott Marine Mammal Rescue and Rapid Response Fund authorizes $7,000,000 annually from 2010 to 2014, with $6,000,000 going to the Secretary of Commerce and $1,000,000 to the Secretary of the Interior. An additional $500,000 is allocated to the Rapid Response Fund each year. Administrative costs and expenses are limited to 6 percent or $80,000, whichever is greater, to implement the program under subsection (a) of the Act. The John H. Prescott Marine Mammal Rescue and Rapid Response Fund authorizes $7,000,000 annually from 2010 to 2014 for the recovery and treatment of marine mammals, data collection for research, facility operation costs, and emergency assistance. The John H. Prescott Marine Mammal Rescue and Rapid Response Fund allows the Secretary to enter into various agreements to carry out activities. It establishes an interest-bearing fund for marine mammal rescue, funded by deposits and contributions, available without restrictions on expenditure. The Marine Mammal Rescue Assistance Act of 2000 limits support for individual projects to $200,000 per 12-month period and allows unexpended funds to remain available until expended. The non-Federal share of costs for activities funded under this section is typically 25 percent of the Federal costs, but the Secretary can waive this requirement for activities using emergency funds from the Fund. In-kind contributions from non-Federal sources can also be applied towards the non-Federal share. The term 'emergency assistance' refers to aid provided for stranding or entangling events that result in immediate increased costs exceeding regular expenses, and may be cyclical or endemic. The Secretary may solicit, accept, receive, hold, administer, and use gifts, devises, and bequests without further approval for emergency assistance. The John H. Prescott Marine Mammal Rescue and Response Funding Program authorizes appropriations for the Marine Mammal Unusual Mortality Event Fund for fiscal years 2010 through 2014.
